metadata.subject: For Radio Host Of the Counterculture, It Was a Strange Trip / The Cold-Case Specialist Who Wants to Put Robert Durst Away

relationships.description: First wife who disappeared and is presumed murdered
Prosecutor pursuing murder charges against Durst
Radio host who interviewed numerous counterculture icons

transactions: Columbia University acquisition of radio archive

analysis.purpose: To report on two separate stories: 1) Bob Fass's personal misfortunes after a house fire, and 2) The prosecution case against Robert Durst
analysis.significance: Combines human interest story with coverage of high-profile criminal case, showing connections between counterculture history and ongoing legal proceedings

notable_quotes: "I could have been roast D.J.," said Mr. Fass. "Have you ever heard the Warren Zevon song 'I was in the House When the House Burned Down?'"
"I'm like the sloth," he told Los Angeles Magazine, referring to the mammal that spend most of its time hanging upside down in trees. "I have this one skill."
"What the hell did I do? Killed them all of course." - Robert Durst muttering off camera in documentary
red_flags: no body in Kathie Durst case

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this news article

illegal_activity.description: This is a New York Times news article reporting on legal proceedings and personal stories, not first-hand evidence of illegal activity

details: New York Times reporters Corey Kilgannon and Charles V. Bagli

public_knowledge.context: Robert Durst case was widely publicized, Bob Fass was a well-known radio personality in counterculture circles

analysis.summary: This New York Times article combines two stories: 1) Radio host Bob Fass's personal misfortunes after a house fire destroyed his new home in Connecticut, and 2) The ongoing prosecution of Robert Durst for the murder of Susan Berman, with prosecutor John Lewin building a cold case spanning decades.
